Legal_Issue: Whether Jankovic qualifies as a member of the family class under Immigration Regulations despite not undergoing a medical examination in 1992
Governing_Law: s. 4(2) and s. 6(5)(a)(ii) of the Immigration Regulations
Evidence_Assessment: Jankovic was in his mother's custody in 1992 and did not undergo a medical exam; father’s application excluded him
Decision_Outcome: Jankovic is not eligible for sponsorship as a member of the family class due to the exclusion in 1992
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate eligibility under family class
Legal_Rule: Dependents exempted from medical examinations cannot be considered part of the family class under s. 4(2) and s. 6(5)(a)(ii)
Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of procedural fairness and humanitarian considerations
Grounds_for_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds, procedural fairness
Review_Standard: Standard of reasonableness applied by Federal Court
Key_Evidence_Considered: Custody status in 1992, absence of medical examination, exclusion from father’s application
Applicant_Challenge: Refusal of permanent residence application based on family class ineligibility
Court_Result: Federal Court upheld immigration officer's decision
Defendant_Response: Application properly assessed under regulatory requirements
Remedy_Requested: Permanent residence through family class sponsorship
Claimant_Status: Applicant for permanent residence under family class
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Failure to meet family class criteria due to lack of medical exam and exclusion in prior application
